Headline.Para: Why Homemade Bombs Are Easy to Make and Hard to Trace; Experts say it isn't difficult to buy necessary materials to construct device

LeadPara.Para: It has been 40 years since Theodore Kaczynski, known as the Unabomber, began terrorizing the country by mailing homemade explosives fashioned with metal pipes, wood and nails. But even now, bomb making still remains incredibly simple, experts say.
Police in Austin have said they believe the blasts that have shaken the city this month are linked precisely because of how the devices were constructed.

TailParas.Para: While no specifics on the materials used in the explosions have been released, bomb experts said it's not hard for would-be bomb makers to buy the necessary materials, and figure out how to construct an explosive device.

"Damn near everything is available if, one, you know where to get it and, two, if you know what you need," said Jim Dower, a retired Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives agent from California who investigated numerous bombings.

When Mr. Dower started with the agency in the 1970s, groups violently opposed to the Vietnam War were often behind the bombings. They learned how to construct explosives from a book called "The Anarchist Cookbook," which featured detailed instructions for making bombs, he said.
"Now, it's very easy for an uninformed person who has the desire or bent to make an explosive device; they can just go on the internet," said Mr. Dower.
Powder for ammunition is readily available, he said. That can often be a component of homemade bombs.

In the 2013 Boston Marathon blasts that killed three and injured more than 175, the attackers used two crude bombs that were assembled from household pressure cookers. The pressure cookers were filled with nails, ball bearings and black powder by the bombers Dzhokhar and Tamerlan Tsarnaev to maximize the damage.

In 2011, Kevin Harpham pleaded guilty for attempting to bomb a Martin Luther King Day memorial march in Spokane, Wash. He used a pipe bomb filled with shrapnel and a chemical found in rat poison that prevents blood from coagulating. Authorities defused the device before it exploded.

At least three of the bombs in the Austin were hidden in packages, which detonated after people opened them. Another bomb, which police said was more sophisticated, used a tripwire—typically made of a thin filament or fishing line—rigged to an explosive device. In that case, the tripwire was triggered when two men made contact with it while walking through an Austin neighborhood on Sunday night.

An unexploded device found Tuesday at a FedEx facility near the Austin airport may provide police with an important break in the case, allowing them to more carefully study the bomber's handywork, said Brig Barker, a former counterterrorism agent with the FBI.

Mr. Barker, who spent much of his career working cases involving jihadists, said bomb makers are often quiet, introverts, who take time to plan their targets and must take special care to avoid detection.
"When you're building a device, you may still have to go to RadioShack several times to buy something, and so you run the risk of alerting the clerk, who sees you in there all the time" he said.
People searching the web for explosive material may also trigger law enforcement scrutiny, Mr. Barker said, which forces a careful bomb maker to be more surreptitious.
Even when police have plenty of explosive material to mine for clues, it can be difficult closing in on a suspect.

Mr. Kaczynski managed to elude capture from 1978 to 1996, killing three people and injuring another twenty-three across the country with mail bombs. An FBI task force examined bomb remnants for clues to no avail.

"These efforts proved of little use in identifying the bomber, who took pains to leave no forensic evidence, building his bombs essentially from 'scrap' materials available almost anywhere," according to an FBI historical accounting of the case.
It was only after the Unabomber's manifesto was published in 1995, and his brother came forward to identify him, that he was finally caught.
